Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), anemia (low red blood cell count), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, ALP, Bil: Elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin, indicating hepatotoxicity.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, indicating nephrotoxicity.
Serum Electrolytes (Potassium, Magnesium: Hyperkalemia (elevated potassium), hypomagnesemia (low magnesium), and hypernatremia (elevated sodium).
Lipid Profile (Cholesterol, Triglyceride: Elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, increasing cardiovascular risk.
Blood Glucose: Hyperglycemia, particularly when combined with corticosteroids.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Reduced levels due to suppression of immune response.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Decreased levels due to suppression of inflammation.
Trough Cyclosporine Levels: Abnormal levels (either too high or too low), impacting efficacy or toxicity.
Urinalysis: Proteinuria, hematuria, or casts indicating renal involvement.
Serum Uric Acid: Elevated levels, potentially leading to gout.
Parathyroid Hormone (PTH): Elevated levels, associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism in chronic kidney disease.
Serum Calcium and Phosphate: Abnormal levels indicating bone metabolism disturbances.
Blood Pressure: Hypertension, frequently reported in patients on cyclosporine.
Serum LDH: Elevated levels in cases of tissue damage or hemolysis.
Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT/Coombs Tes: Positive in cases of drug-induced hemolytic anemia.
